Opposing Force? I get it! Oh NOW i get it...

Gearbox set out to do what with Opposing Force and Blue Shift, what your childhood mind did with Reservoir Dogs; fill in and flesh out the parallel stories.

Opposing Force puts you in the shoes of Colonel Shepherd, a soldier brought in as on of the military grunts to cover up the black mesa incident. But lo and behold as similar to how Gordon Freeman's regular day suddenly changed pace, Shepherds duties of covering up and cleaning up the incident at Black Mesa goes off the deep end with the introduction of a separate Black Ops task force to cover up the military clean up as well as the beginning Alien invasion of the  Seven hour war.

An amazing game that expands upon the arsenal of weapons given in Half Life to allow you the most diverse gunplay in the franchise. The Gold Source engine's polish is paramount in this installation.

Have fun.

I loved the fact of switching sides over to the marines, though I did want to actually be with my main squad instead of crashing, however, the game was still fun overall and I hope valve actually makes it canon,

Half-Life: Opposing Force is quite the challenge in my opinion. You take the role of Adrian Shepard, a marine who was sent to clean up Black Mesa after the incident, however like Gordon Freeman, once he enters Black Mesa he is faced with the challenge of having to fight his way through Xen's Aliens and Black Ops, who were sent to clean up the marines because they failed their mission. Game play remains the same with some new but minor mechanics. Stealth is something that is necessary in this game as there are enemies who are much, much stronger & charging in might get you killed in an instant. It could just be me, but because of the strength increase for enemies, this makes this game super difficult which isn't a bad thing, but coming from Half-Life which was more moderate with it's difficulty, it seems a little overwhelming. Overall, Story remains similar to Half-Life, game play is similar, sound & video is excellent for it's time, this truly is a great game that I recommend you play after completing the original Half-Life. 7/10

One of the best expansion pack ever made. This time, you play as the Corporal Adrian Shepard, one of the many soldiers sent to "clean up" the big mess that created Gordon Freeman in Black Mesa after the resonance cascade. лучшое дополнения к half-life  
1) новая раса X
2)богатый выбор оружия 
3)да и захватывающий сюжет солдата H.E.C.O. по имени Адриан Шепард

Set during the events of Half-Life 1, here you play as Corporal Adrian Shepard, a member of the military unit that Gordon Freeman fought in HL1. Here, they are revealed to be the fictional Hazardous Environment Combat Unit, or HECU for short, and they seem to pull equipment and stuff from every other branch of the military. Anyways, when Adrian's squad is sent to help contain the Xen invasion of Black Mesa, their Osprey gets shot down, and Adrian is separated from them. When he comes to, the military is ordering a complete evacuation of Black Mesa, and so he tries to reach the extraction while shooting any and all aliens that come his way, only to discover that the Black Ops soldiers from HL1 were not sent as backup for the HECU Marines, but to remove EVERYTHING, including the Marines, from the area. To make matters worse, [i]ANOTHER[/i] group of aliens, Race X, starts invading, and are hostile to both the humans AND the aliens from Xen. It ends up coming down to Adrian to stop them too.

If you liked the gameplay of Half-Life 1, you're going to like this one too. Its still rather fun and challenging at times. The new toys Adrian Shepard gets to play with here, like a sniper rifle, machine gun, and various alien weaponry, are great, along with any returning weapons. Sometimes you'll come across friendly NPCs in the form of HECU Marines, and they add a level of fun to combat, and are occasionally important to progress. When there is music, it is STILL absolutely fantastic.

This expansion pack is a solid recommend from me.

A better Half Life 2 than HL2- Lemme explain
Half-Life 2 is a great game that greatly advances the plotline of the Half Life series, but Opposing Force is a better direct sequel to HL1. 
And unlike HL1 + 2, it does what it sets out to do much quicker. It's about half the length of HL1, but each part is more substantial.
The weapons are definitely improvements over HL1's, and while the new Aliens are challenging, it's still fun to slaughter them. 
If you like Doom and are looking for a HL equivalent, this is definitely it.
Valve please bring back Cpl. Shephard he's the bravest of marines

Ok so like actually just wait for the fan remake mod for Black Mesa. This and the other original half life games are very very rough and I don't recommend playing these if you've just gotten into the series or haven't played them back when they were released. 
This one specifically felt very very long and I found was obnoxiously difficult or confusing in areas. I frequently found myself running out of ammo in almost every weapon and with extremely low health not knowing where to go or what to do.
I will say that this is quite an interesting and neat expansion to the original half life but it shares too many of the flaws and problems the original half life had for me to actually recommend playing this outside of nostalgia for goldsource. I encountered plenty of bugs relating to weapons breaking after attempting to fire underwater as well.

All in all. Wait for the fan remake for black mesa (either titled Military or with HECU in the name somewhere I can't recall exactly) as I'm sure it will improve and fix many of the issues that were present in the original release.

Yet another game that makes me wish I there was a "maybe" recommendation option, but given there isn't, I'm going to have to go with no.

Half-Life: Opposing Force is basically just more Half-Life, but not as good. If you really, [i]really[/i] want more Half-Life, Opposing Force will probably do it for you. There's some pretty neat ideas scattered throughout. But put up against how great Half-Life is really makes you appreciate a lot of the clever visual cuing and other level design tricks that Valve uses to make one cohesive journey.

There is some neat new stuff introduced in the game, but a number of them are pretty flawed. You can get AI squad members to fight with you, occasionally, for a little bit. They aren't particularly competent, and can't navigate difficult terrain, so even if they do survive for a while, eventually you'll be forced to leave them behind. You can climb and swing from ropes, but it never quite works the way you expect it to, and ultimately just made me wish they had all been just ladders, instead. Night vision goggles replace the Half-Life flashlight. While the original Half-Life flashlight is pretty bad, having your whole screen green for long periods of time is also annoying, and with the amount of dark sections in this, you better get used to green. Also, the voltigore nests are just annoying.

That said, there are some nice new weapons included, including a couple alien weapons that are actually useful, unlike the Hivehand. There are some neat new enemies, and getting to see some areas from the base game from a different perspective is neat.

Ultimately, this isn't a bad expansion, but it also isn't easy to recommend. With the number of truly great games out there, I'd say Opposing Force can be safely skipped by most.
